intro: Siphokentia pachypus, commonly known as the Pukapuka palm, is a rare and endemic species native to the island of Pukapuka in the Cook Islands. It is a member of the Arecaceae family and is characterized by its tall, slender trunk and large, pinnate leaves. The plant produces small, yellow flowers that develop into orange, fleshy fruits. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered critically endangered. Conservation efforts are ongoing to protect this unique botanical species from extinction.
